title: 106_s2285
content: Temporary reduction in fuel taxes on gasoline, diesel fuel, kerosene, and aviation fuel by 4.3 cents, or to zero. During a specified period, fuel taxes on gasoline, diesel fuel, and kerosene will be reduced by 4.3 cents per gallon, with the possibility of being reduced to zero if the national average price of unleaded regular gasoline reaches $2.00 per gallon. During a specified period, fuel taxes on gasoline, diesel fuel, and kerosene will be reduced by 4.3 cents per gallon, with the possibility of being reduced to zero if the national average price of unleaded regular gasoline reaches $2.00 per gallon. The rates of tax applicable are based on specific fuel types and vehicles. If the reduction in taxes would exceed the Federal on-budget surplus, the Secretary, in consultation with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, will protect the Social Security Trust Fund. The Secretary will adjust tax reductions if they exceed the Federal surplus, ensuring a pro rata reduction for each tax rate. Trust fund deposits for Highway and Airport funds will be maintained by treating the revenue reduction as taxes received. The applicable period for these changes is from April 15, 2000, to before January 1, 2001. During the applicable period from April 15, 2000, to before January 1, 2001, there will be a temporary reduction in the tax on aviation fuel as specified in the Internal Revenue Code. The reduction in tax revenues will be treated as taxes received in the Treasury to maintain trust fund deposits. During the applicable period from April 15, 2000, to before January 1, 2001, there will be a temporary reduction in the tax on aviation fuel as specified in the Internal Revenue Code. The term 'applicable period' means the period beginning after April 15, 2000, and ending before January 1, 2001. The amendments made by this section shall take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 2. FLOOR STOCK REFUNDS. Before the tax reduction date, if tax has been imposed on any liquid under specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code, and on that date the liquid is held by a dealer for sale without being used, the taxpayer can claim a credit or refund for the excess tax paid. Claims must be filed within 6 months of the tax reduction date. On the tax reduction date, if liquid is held by a dealer, the dealer must request a refund or credit from the taxpayer within 3 months. No credit or refund is allowed for liquid in retail stocks. Definitions for "dealer" and "held by a dealer" are provided in this section. The terms "dealer" and "held by a dealer" are defined in section 6412 of the Code, with "dealer" including a producer. The "tax reduction date" is April 16, 2000. Rules similar to section 6412 of the Code apply for this section. SEC. 3. FLOOR STOCKS TAX. Imposition of Tax: A floor stocks tax is imposed on any liquid held on the floor stocks tax date, equivalent to the tax that would have been imposed under specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code. Liability and payment methods are outlined, with the tax due within 6 months after the floor stocks tax date. The floor stocks tax is due within 6 months after the floor stocks tax date. Definitions include terms like "held by a person", "gasoline", "diesel fuel", and "aviation fuel". The floor stocks tax date is January 1, 2001, and the applicable period is after April 15, 2000, and before January 1, 2001. The Secretary refers to the Secretary of the Treasury or their delegate. The tax imposed on gasoline, diesel fuel, kerosene, or aviation fuel by the Secretary of the Treasury or delegate has exceptions for exempt uses, fuel held in vehicle tanks, and certain amounts of fuel not exceeding 4,000 gallons on the floor stocks tax date. The tax exemptions for gasoline, diesel fuel, kerosene, or aviation fuel include limits of 4,000 gallons for certain fuels and 2,000 gallons for aviation gasoline, diesel fuel, kerosene, or aviation fuel held by individuals. Fuel exempt from tax under specific subsections is not considered. Controlled groups are defined for this subsection. Controlled groups are defined as all persons treated as a single entity, with specific criteria for corporations and nonincorporated persons under common control. The definition follows guidelines outlined in section 1563 of the tax code, with a substitution of "more than 50 percent" for "at least 80 percent." The principles of subparagraph (A) apply to a group of persons under common control, even if not all are corporations. Other laws, including penalties, applicable to taxes imposed by section 4081 or 4091, also apply to floor stock taxes imposed by subsection (a). SEC. 4. Benefits of tax reduction should be passed on to consumers. The sense of Congress is that consumers should immediately benefit from tax reductions, and transportation fuel producers should lower prices accordingly. A study will be conducted to ensure the tax reduction is passed on to consumers. The Comptroller General of the United States will report the results of a study on tax reduction to the Senate and House committees by September 30, 2000.
